thread.title_full: NFL too much for 19-year-olds to handle, no matter how exceptional

author: freep.com
title: NFL too much for 19-year-olds to handle, no matter how exceptional
text:
MORE Why not let 15-year-olds vote if they choose?
Aren't our children supposedly the future victims of our massive federal debt? If they're doomed to inherit the fiscal ills of their elders, shouldn't they have a constitutional say in helping determine that future even if the vast majority of that age aren't intellectually mature or politically sophisticated enough to handle such responsibility?
It's a crazy idea, because the onus should be protecting the 99% even if it might unfairly punish that special 1%.
LSU running back Leonard Fournette is one of those rarities. He's ready for the NFL now — a quarter into his sophomore season. He gains little taking another snap for the Tigers. And he legitimately earns even less (at least in actual spendable dollars) continually playing a sport that perpetuates a sham of amateurism. LSU hosts Eastern Michigan tonight.
But while the NFL rule mandating that college players wait three years before gaining draft eligibility seems unnecessarily punitive to Fournette, it must be viewed within the larger context of hopefully saving the other 19-year-olds who crazily think they're ready for the physical and emotional rigors of NFL football at a high level.
LSU coach Les Miles said this week that he doesn't see any scenario in which Fournette would sit out his junior season, saving himself for the 2017 NFL draft. And, of course, Miles blamed the media.
"What you have to realize is that people are going to say things," Miles said. "If you're gainfully employed and you're sitting in front of a microphone, you have to say something that stirs the pot. OK? So to me, there's a lot of people stirring the pot just to make controversy."
The smartest strategy for Fournette is playing next season. But this also is where the NCAA should provide even better injury insurance protection for the top-rated running backs. It's fair without being foolish.
Everyone has the right to fail if they so choose. But isn't there also a greater responsibility to reduce the collective risk of failure — even if it means potentially unfairly penalizing those rare talents?
